para.text: In these regulations, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“ASME Code” means the “ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code” of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers with revisions, amendments, and interpretations adopted by the Board of Boiler Rules.
“Antique boiler” means a boiler that is:
Fabricated and stamped:
In accordance with the ASME Code or another nationally recognized boiler construction standard; and
More than 30 years before the date of the inspection;
Operated primarily for demonstration, exhibition, or instructional purposes and not for profit; or
Constructed, inspected, and stamped in accordance with the ASME Code and registered with the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessels Inspectors to replace a historical boiler.
“Approved” means approved by the Board of Boiler Rules.
“Authorized Inspection Agency” means an entity that:

Is accredited in accordance with the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors NB-369, Qualifications and Duties for Authorized Inspection Agencies Performing Inservice Inspection Activities and Qualifications for Inspectors of Boilers and Pressure Vessels;
Is accredited in accordance with the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors NB-371, Accreditation of Owner-User Inspection Organizations (OUIO); or
Meets the qualifications and definition of the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors NB-360, Criteria for Acceptance of Authorized Inspection Agencies for New Construction.
“Authorized Insurer” means an authorized inspection agency licensed to insure boilers and pressure vessels in Maryland.
“Board” means the Board of Boiler Rules.
“Boiler external piping” means piping which:
Begins where the boiler proper terminates at the:
First circumferential joint for welded end connections;
Face of the first flange in bolted flanged connections; or
First threaded joint in threaded connections; and
Extends up to and including the valve or valves required by Section I or Section IV of the ASME Code.
“Certificate of Competency” means a certificate issued by the Chief Boiler Inspector indicating the suitability and fitness of an individual to inspect boilers and pressure vessels in Maryland.
“Certificate inspection” means an inspection the report of which is used by the Chief Boiler Inspector to determine whether to issue a certificate.
“Certificate of inspection for repair or alteration” means the certificate inspection performed after a repair or alteration to determine suitability of the object for return to service.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.

“Condemned boiler or pressure vessel” means a boiler or pressure vessel that has been inspected and declared unsafe or declared disqualified under legal requirements by an inspector who is authorized to take such action and who has applied a stamp or mark designating condemnation.
“Electric boiler” means a boiler in which the source of heat is electricity.
“Existing boiler or pressure vessel installation” means:
A boiler constructed, installed, placed in operation, or contracted for before July 1, 1969, excluding antique boilers, historical boilers or model steam boilers; or
A pressure vessel constructed, installed, placed in operation, or contracted for before January 1, 1974, excluding antique boilers, historical boilers or model steam boilers.
“External inspection” means an inspection made when a boiler or pressure vessel is in operation.
“Follow up inspection” means an inspection performed after a boiler or pressure vessel has been determined to be nonconforming with applicable laws and regulations.
Heating Boiler.
“Heating boiler” means:
A steam boiler that operates at pressures not exceeding 15 PSIG; or
A hot water boiler operated at pressures not exceeding 160PSIG or temperatures not exceeding 250°F at or near the boiler outlet.
“Heating boiler” includes a vessel used in connection with it as an expansion tank.
“High-pressure, high-temperature water boiler” means a water boiler that operates at pressures exceeding 160 PSIG or temperatures exceeding 250°F at or near the boiler outlet.
“Historical boiler” means a boiler that is:
Riveted and/or welded construction;
Not under the jurisdiction of the Federal Railroad Administration;
Not used for profit; and
An antique boiler, steam tractor, traction engine, hobby steam boiler, or portable steam boiler that is preserved, restored, and maintained for demonstration, viewing, or educational purposes.
“Hobby steam boiler” means a model steam boiler.
“Hot water heating boiler” means a heating boiler furnishing hot water circulated to return to itself.
“Hot water supply boiler” means a heating boiler furnishing hot water for use external to itself.
“Individually fabricated” means constructed, inspected, and stamped in accordance with the ASME Code, or other standard accepted by the Chief Boiler Inspector.
“Inspector” means the chief boiler inspector, a deputy boiler inspector, or a special inspector.
"Installer” means an individual, firm, association, corporation, or other entity that installs or constructs boilers or pressure vessels.

“Internal inspection” means an examination as complete as possible of the internal and external surfaces of a boiler or pressure vessel conducted while it is not in operation, and with all manhole plates, hand hole plates, and other coverings of inspection openings removed.
“Kitchen” means an area used for the preparation or processing of food for human consumption.
“Kitchen equipment boiler” means a boiler located in a kitchen, and used for cooking or related purposes.
“Lap-seam crack” means a crack in a lap-seam of a boiler or pressure vessel parallel to a longitudinal joint, either between or adjacent to rivet holes.
“Maryland inspection report form” means the form submitted by an inspector and available on the Department’s website.
“Miniature boiler” means a boiler when none of the following limitations are exceeded:
16 inches inside diameter of shell;
20 square feet heating surface, except for an electric boiler;
5 cubic feet gross volume, exclusive of casing and insulation; and
100 psig maximum allowable working pressure.
“Model steam boiler” means a boiler that is individually fabricated for non-commercial use and that is used primarily for demonstration, exhibition, or educational purposes, and not used for profit.

“Maximum allowable operating pressure” means the maximum pressure at which a boiler or pressure vessel is permitted to operate as determined by an inspector after an inspection and which is equal to or less than the maximum allowable working pressure.
“Maximum allowable working pressure” means the maximum pressure at which a boiler or pressure vessel is designed to operate as determined by the manufacturer in accordance with the construction code.
“Modular boiler system” means a series of boiler units specifically designed to be used singularly or together in sequential operation.
“National Board” means the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors.
“NBIC” means the National Board Inspection Code.
“New boiler or pressure vessel installation” means:
A boiler constructed, installed, placed in operation, or contracted for after July 1, 1969; or
A pressure vessel constructed, installed, placed in operation, or contracted for after January 1, 1974.
“Nonstandard boiler or pressure vessel” means a boiler or pressure vessel that does not bear the stamp of:
Maryland;
Another jurisdiction which has adopted a standard of construction equivalent to that required by the Board of Boiler Rules;
The ASME; or
The National Board.
"Owner" means a person, firm, or corporation owning or operating a boiler or pressure vessel within Maryland.

“Owner-user inspection service” means an owner of a boiler or pressure vessel in Maryland, who maintains a regularly established inspection department whose inspection procedures meet the applicable requirements of the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors and are acceptable to the Board.
“Person” means an installer, owner, or operator of a boiler or pressure vessel, a repair organization, or a company licensed to insure or inspect boilers and pressure vessels in the State.
“Portable boiler or pressure vessel” means a boiler or pressure vessel that is not historical but meets the following requirements:
Is set on a frame, platform or trailer; and
Is designed to be moved to different locations for use.
“Portable steam boiler” means a historical boiler that is:
Not self-propelled;
Set on a frame, platform, or trailer; and
Designed to be moved to different locations for use.
“Power boiler” means a boiler in which steam or other vapor is generated at a pressure of more than 15 PSIG, and includes a high-pressure, high-temperature water boiler.
“PSIG” means pounds per square inch gauge.
“Standard boiler or pressure vessel” means a boiler or pressure vessel that:
Bears the stamp of Maryland;
Bears the stamp of another jurisdiction which has adopted a standard of construction equivalent to that required by the Board of Boiler Rules;
Bears the stamps of both ASME and the National Board; or
Is of equivalent safe construction acceptable to the Board.
“Used boiler or pressure vessel” means a boiler or pressure vessel which has been removed from its original setting and reinstalled at the same or different location.
“Water heater” means a closed vessel with openings through which water may flow and includes:
An apparatus by which heat is generated;
Controls necessary to prevent pressures greater than 160 psig and water temperatures greater than 210 degrees F; and
Potable water that is withdrawn for external use.
“Workday” means a day that is not a Saturday, a Sunday, or a State holiday.
The following documents are incorporated by reference to the extent that they are referenced in this chapter:
ASME 2019 Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, an International Code; and
National Board Inspection Code — NBIC, 2019 Edition.
The following documents are incorporated by reference in their entirety:
ASME B31.1 — 2018 Edition, Power Piping (American Society of Mechanical Engineers);
ASME B31.3 — 2018 Edition, Process Piping (American Society of Mechanical Engineers);
ASME CSD-1 — 2018 Edition, Controls and Safety Devices for Automatically Fired Boilers (American Society of Mechanical Engineers) as amended in §C of this regulation; and
NFPA 85, Boiler and Combustion Systems Hazards Code — 2019 Edition (National Fire Protection Association).
Controls and Safety Devices for Automatically Fired Boilers (CSD-1) (American Society of Mechanical Engineers).
The requirements of ASME CSD-1 in effect at the time a boiler is installed apply to:
Power boilers regardless of fuel input;
Other boilers with a fuel input of greater than 2,500,000 Btu per hour and less than 12,500,000 Btu per hour; and
Other boilers with a fuel input of 2,500,000 Btu per hour or less, except that Section CF of CSD-1 does not apply to these boilers.
The following are exempt from the requirements of ASME CSD-1:
Water heaters stamped either “H” or “HLW” and used as potable water heaters, if the water temperature is less than 210°F and the water pressure is less than 160 PSIG;
Miniature boilers, except as required in Regulation .37 of this chapter;
Kitchen equipment boilers, except as required in Regulation .38 of this chapter; and
Historical boilers.

section.heading: Compliance.
section.text: In the event of a conflict between a regulation in this chapter and a code section incorporated by reference, the provisions of this chapter control.

para.text: Clearance.
Except for a water heater or a modular boiler system, a new or replacement boiler installed in a new or existing building shall be installed consistent with:
Or exceeding, the manufacturer's recommendations for clearance; and
The space requirements of §A(6) of this regulation.
In the event manufacturer recommendations for clearance are not provided, a new or replacement boiler installed in a new or existing building, shall:
Have at least 3 feet between:
The top of the boiler and the ceiling, and
Each side of the boiler and the adjacent wall or other structure; and
Comply with the conditions of §A(6) of this regulation.

The distance between or around a new or replacement boiler in a modular boiler system installed in a new or existing building shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations while ensuring:
There are 3 feet between each side of the perimeter of the boiler system and the adjacent wall or structure; and
The conditions in §A(6) of this regulation are met.

The distance between or around a water heater installed in a new or existing building shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations while ensuring the conditions of §A(6) of this regulation are met.
A boiler or pressure vessel having a manhole shall have 5 feet clearance from the manhole opening to any wall, ceiling, or piping that prevents entrance through the manhole.
A boiler or pressure vessel shall be located to provide adequate space for:
Proper operation of the boiler or pressure vessel and its appurtenances;
Inspection of all surfaces, tubes, water-walls, economizers, piping, valves, and other equipment; and
Required maintenance and the repair and replacement of tubes.
Ladders and Runways.
When necessary to afford safe access, a steel runway or platform of standard construction shall be installed across the tops of adjacent boilers or pressure vessels, or at another convenient level.
When a valve or appurtenance requiring frequent manipulation cannot be reached or operated from the floor, a platform or other safe means of operation shall be provided.
A platform or runway shall:
Be at least 24 inches wide;
Have standard handrails and toe boards; and
Provide at least 7 feet, 6 inches overhead clearance.
A runway shall:
Have at least two means of exit, located remotely from each other; and
Be connected to floor level by:
A permanent stairway, or
An inclined ladder.
Each elevation in a boiler room shall have at least two exits, located remotely from each other, if the room:
Exceeds 500 square feet floor area; and
Contains one or more boilers having a fuel-burning capacity of 1,000,000 Btu per hour, or equivalent electrical heat input.
A boiler room shall have a permanent source of outside air to:
Permit satisfactory combustion of fuel; and
Provide proper ventilation of the boiler under normal operating conditions.
Louvered area.
The total requirements of all burners for all fired pressure vessels in a boiler room shall be used to determine the louver sizes, whether the pressure vessels are fired by coal, oil, or gas.
The minimum net free louvered area shall be at least 1 square foot.
The minimum dimension of air openings may not be less than 3 inches.
Ducts, when used, shall be of the same cross-sectional area as the free area of the openings to which they connect.
The following configurations shall be used:
Two permanent openings:
One opening shall start within 12 inches of the ceiling, and one opening shall start within 12 inches of the floor;
The openings shall connect directly, or by ducts, with the outdoors or with crawl or attic spaces that freely connect with the outdoors;

Where directly connecting with the outdoors or where connecting to the outdoors through vertical ducts, each opening shall have a minimum free area of 1 square inch per 4,000 Btu per hour of total input rating, or total relieving capacity, of all fired pressure vessels, whichever is greater; and

Where connecting to the outdoors through horizontal ducts, each opening shall have a minimum free area of 1 square inch per 2,000 Btu per hour of total input rating, or total relieving capacity, of all fired pressure vessels, whichever is greater; or
One permanent opening:
The opening shall start within 12 inches of the ceiling;
The opening shall directly connect with the outdoors, or shall connect through a vertical or horizontal duct to the outdoors or with crawl or attic spaces that freely connect to the outdoors; and
The opening shall have a free open area of 1 square inch per 3,000 Btu per hour of total input rating, or total relieving capacity, of all fired pressure vessels, whichever is greater.

para.text: Mechanical Combustion and Ventilation.
Mechanical ventilation may be used to supply combustion air or ventilation air, or both, to a boiler room.
When mechanical ventilation is used:
The firing device shall be interlocked with the fan so that the firing device cannot operate without proven airflow;
The velocity of the air passing through the louvers cannot exceed 500 feet per minute; and
The total air delivered shall be equal to or exceed 0.5 CFM per 1,000 Btu per hour of total input rating or total required relieving capacity, whichever is greater.
Water Heater Combustion Air Ventilation Requirements.
Hot water heaters in excess of 200,000 Btu per hour up to but not including 1,000,000 Btu per hour, that are located in their own equipment room, shall have at least:
1 permanent source of outside air; and
1 square foot of total net free louvered air space.
Hot water heaters of 1,000,000 Btu per hour or greater shall follow manufacturer's requirements.
Hot water heaters with inputs and required relieving capacities less than 200,000 Btu per hour are not covered by this regulation.
Automatic Low Water Fuel Cutoff or Water Feeding Device.

An automatically fired steam or vapor system boiler shall have a low water fuel cutoff that automatically cuts off the fuel supply when the water surface falls to the lowest safe level. The following apply:
A water feeding device shall be:
Constructed so that the water inlet valve cannot feed water into the boiler through the float chamber, and
Located to supply the necessary feedwater;
The lowest safe water line shall be not lower than the lowest visible part of the water glass.
A fuel or feedwater control device may be attached:
Directly to a boiler; or
To the tapped openings provided to attach a water glass directly to a boiler, provided that for low-pressure boilers:

Connections from the boiler are made with nonferrous tees or Y's at least 1/2 inch pipe size between the boiler and the water glass, so that the water glass is attached directly and as close as possible to the boiler,
Straightaway tapping of the Y or tee takes the water glass fittings, and
The side outlet of the Y or tee takes the fuel cutoff or water feeding device.
The ends of all nipples shall be reamed to full-size diameter.

A design using a float and float bowl shall have a vertical straightway valve drain pipe located at the lowest point in the water-equalizing pipe connections by which the bowl and equalizing pipe can be flushed and the device tested.
Blowoff Equipment.
Blowdown from a boiler that enters a sanitary sewer system, or blowdown that is a hazard to life or property, shall pass through blowoff equipment to ensure that the maximum:
Temperature of water leaving the equipment is 150°F; and
Pressure of blowdown leaving the equipment is 5 PSIG.
Blowoff equipment shall:
Use piping and fittings between the boiler and the blowoff tank that comply with the ASME Code, Section I, paragraph PG-59;
Be fabricated of material that complies with the ASME Code, Section II;
Be fitted with openings that facilitate cleaning and inspection; and
Conform to the rules for boiler blowoff equipment established by the National Board.
Discharge of safety valves, blowoff pipes, and other outlets shall be located to prevent injury to personnel.
Boiler-Door Latches.
Firing Doors.
The firing doors on a watertube boiler shall:
Open inward;
Be equipped with effective fastening devices; or
Be constructed to prevent the doors from being blown open by pressure on the furnace side.
Except for coal openings on a downdraft or similar furnace:
Door fastenings shall be positive self-locking; and
Friction contacts, latches, or bolts actuated by springs may not be used.
An explosion door, if used and located in a setting wall within 7 feet of a firing floor or operating platform, shall have substantial deflectors to divert a blast.
Except for an explosion door, a door not used during boiler firing may be equipped with bolts or fastenings.
Pressure-Reducing Valve.
When a pressure-reducing valve is used:

If the piping or equipment on the low-pressure side of the reducing valve does not meet the requirements for full initial pressure, at least one relief or safety valve shall be installed on the low-pressure side of the reducing valve;
The relief or safety valves shall adjoin or be as close as possible to the reducing valve;
When a relief or safety valve is vented to the atmosphere, proper protection shall be provided to prevent escaping fluid from causing injury or damage;
The combined discharge capacity of relief or safety valves shall be such that the pressure rating of the lowest pressure piping or equipment cannot be exceeded if the reducing valve sticks open.
Bypass Around Reducing Valves.
A hand-controlled bypass around a reducing valve may be used.
If a bypass is used around a reducing valve, the safety valve on the low-pressure side shall have sufficient relief capacity to prevent overpressuring the low-pressure side.

para.text: A boiler or pressure vessel shall have masonry or structural supports of sufficient strength and rigidity to:
Safely support the boiler or pressure vessel and its contents; and
Prevent excessive vibration of the boiler, pressure vessel, or connecting piping.

section.heading: Factor of Safety--Increase for Existing Installation.

para.text: An inspector may increase the factor of safety of an existing installation if the condition of the boiler or pressure vessel warrants the increase.
Appeal Procedure.
An owner may appeal an increase in a factor of safety to the Board.
Upon appeal, the Board may request that the chief boiler inspector and a deputy boiler inspector or special inspector conduct a joint inspection.
Each inspector shall submit a report to the Board.
Based on the reports submitted, the Board shall make a final determination of the appropriate factor of safety.
A fired jacketed steam kettle may be installed if it is:
Constructed and stamped in accordance with the ASME Code, Section I, IV, or VIII, Division 1; and
Registered with the National Board.
A gas-fired jacketed steam kettle may be constructed in accordance with the ASME Code, Section VIII, Division 1, provided that:
Welded joints having contact with products of combustion are Type No. 1 of Table UW-12;
The minimum thickness of a part subject to pressure is, for:
Carbon steel, 1/4 inch, or
Stainless steel or nonferrous pressure parts, as specified in the ASME Code, Section VIII, Division 1, Subsection C;
A part having contact with products of combustion is, for:
Carbon steel, pressure vessel quality, and
Austenitic stainless steel, either extra-low carbon or stabilized grade;
Structural grade carbon steel is not used for any pressure part;
The operating pressure of the jacket does not exceed 50 PSI;
A vessel constructed in accordance with this regulation:
Is inspected by an authorized inspector, and
Is not marked with the UM symbol;
Steam or water is not withdrawn from the jacket for use external to the vessel;
The capacity of the safety valve in pounds of steam per hour is at least equal to the BTU rating of the burner divided by 1,000; and
The jacket has:
A pressure gage,
A water gage glass,
A separate connection, fitted with a check valve and stop valve, for adding water to the jacket while the vessel is not under pressure,
An automatic gas valve controlled by pressure or temperature to maintain the steam pressure in the jacket below the safety valve setting,
A low water cutoff to stop the flow of fuel to the burner if the water in the jacket drops below the lowest permissible water level as established by the manufacturer, and
A safety pilot control to stop the flow of fuel to both the main burner and the pilot burner in case of pilot flame failure.
A burner in a gas-fired installation shall be tested and certified by the American Gas Association.
A gas-fired boiler shall have a vent or flue that terminates at an acceptable location outside the building.
The size of the vent or flue shall be:
That recommended by the boiler manufacturer;
At least 4 inches in diameter or equivalent area; and
If the horizontal run exceeds 10 feet, at least 6 inches in diameter or equivalent area.
A special inspector who finds a hazardous condition affecting the safety of a boiler or pressure vessel shall notify the chief boiler inspector in accordance with Regulation .28 of this chapter.
If a special inspector determines that a boiler or pressure vessel is unsafe for operation:
The inspector shall:
Notify the owner promptly;
Specify the repair or corrective measure required to achieve compliance with regulations; and
If the owner does not agree to take the required action promptly, notify the chief boiler inspector immediately;
Until the required repair or corrective measure is completed:
Use of the boiler or pressure vessel is prohibited; and
The chief boiler inspector shall suspend the inspection certificate, if any.
If, upon inspection, the chief boiler inspector or a deputy boiler inspector declares a boiler or pressure vessel unsafe:
The boiler or pressure vessel shall be condemned and stamped in accordance with Regulation .30 of this chapter; and
Use or operation of the condemned boiler or pressure vessel shall subject the owner to the penalties provided by Public Safety Article, §12-915, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A hearing shall be held in accordance with the requirements of the Administrative Procedure Act, Title 10, Subtitle 2, State Government Article, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Commissioner delegates the authority to issue a proposed decision on a citation or penalty to the Office of Administrative Hearings.
A proposed decision of the Office of Administrative Hearings becomes a final order of the Commissioner 20 days after the date it is issued, unless:
The person found to have violated Public Safety Article, Title 12, Subtitle 9, Annotated Code of Maryland, or a regulation or order issued to carry out this law, requests a review; or
The Commissioner orders review.
Review of Proceedings Before the Commissioner.
A request for review by a person found to have violated Public Safety Article, Title 12, Subtitle 9, Annotated Code of Maryland, or a regulation or order issued to carry out this law, shall:
Be in writing;
Contain a concise statement identifying each portion of the determination for which a review is requested;
Be filed with the Commissioner within 20 days after the date the determination is issued; and
Be mailed by the requesting party to all other parties to the proceeding.
Affected parties have the opportunity to present argument to the Commissioner based on the record before the Office of Administrative Hearings.
Order of the Commissioner.
After review of the proceedings, with or without a hearing, the Commissioner shall:
Issue an order based on findings of fact; and
Mail copies of the order to all affected parties.
The Commissioner’s order shall affirm, modify, or vacate the citation or proposed penalty, or direct other appropriate relief.
Hearings Before the Board of Boiler Rules.
A hearing before the Board of Boiler Rules shall be held before at least four members of the Board.
A request for postponement of a hearing may not be considered unless the presiding officer receives a request:
In writing;
At least 5 days before the scheduled hearing date; and
Setting forth the reasons for the request.
Presiding Officer.
At a hearing before the Board, the chairman of the Board or, in the chairman’s absence, the chairman’s designee, shall be the presiding officer.
A presiding officer may:
Administer oaths and affirmations;
Rule on offers of proof and procedural matters;
Regulate the course of the hearing, including the conduct of parties and counsel;
Receive relevant evidence;
Examine a witness; and
Take other action authorized by statute or regulation.
A hearing shall be recorded verbatim.
Hearing Procedure.
The presiding officer shall:
Call the title of the case;
Briefly explain the purpose and nature of the hearing;
Recite any charges, complaints, or other matters involved;
Administer the oath to all persons who are to testify; and
Receive any stipulation entered into by the parties.
Counsel or a party may address any preliminary matter, exception, or motion.
The following exhibits shall be introduced:
A copy of the petition, complaint, or other matter involved in the hearing; and
A copy of the notice of hearing.

In a hearing on an application for variance, the applicant shall proceed first and present evidence to demonstrate either that the subject regulation is unreasonable or that it imposes an undue burden on the applicant, and that equivalent safety can be maintained. The presenter of evidence shall then present information obtained as a result of the agency’s investigation of the application.
Subject to statutes and rules governing the practice of law, a party or counsel representing a party may:
Call witnesses;
Offer evidence, including rebuttal evidence;
Cross-examine a witness called by another party or the agency; and
Present argument and summation.
Any member of the Board may examine a witness.
The Board may permit or require a party to file a written memorandum, which may include proposed findings of fact and conclusions of law.
The Board shall:
Issue a written determination which includes findings of fact and conclusions of law, and an order disposing of the proceedings; and
Promptly serve a copy of the determination on each party or the party's counsel of record.

A party aggrieved by a final order issued pursuant to this regulation may obtain judicial review by filing a written petition with the appropriate circuit court within 30 days of issuance of the final order.

section.heading: Heating Boiler — Existing Installation: Maximum Allowable Working Pressure

para.text: The maximum allowable working pressure on a standard boiler may not exceed the pressure stamped or cast by the manufacturer on:
The boiler; or
A plate secured to the boiler.
The maximum allowable working pressure on:
The shell of a nonstandard riveted heating boiler shall be determined in accordance with Regulation .22 of this chapter, except that the maximum allowable working pressure on a:
Steam heating boiler may not exceed 15 PSIG; and
Hot water boiler may not exceed:
160 PSIG, or
A nonstandard steel or wrought iron heating boiler of welded construction:
May not exceed 15 PSIG for steam; and
For service other than steam, shall be calculated in accordance with the ASME Code, Section IV.
A nonstandard boiler composed principally of cast iron, or having a cast iron shell or heads and steel or wrought iron tubes, may not exceed:
15 PSIG for steam service; and
30 PSIG for hot water service.

section.heading: Heating Boiler — Existing Installation: Safety Valve.

para.text: A steam boiler shall have at least one safety valve which is:
Officially rated;
Of the spring pop type; and
Adjusted and sealed to discharge at a pressure not greater than 15 PSI.
A seal shall be attached in a manner to prevent the valve from being disassembled without breaking the seal.
A safety valve shall be arranged so that it cannot be reset to relieve at a pressure higher than the maximum allowable working pressure of the boiler.
Body Drain.
The manufacturer shall provide a body drain connection below seat level.
A body drain may not be plugged during or after field installation.
If a valve exceeds 2 inch pipe size, the drain hole shall be tapped at least 3/8 inch pipe size.
A valve less than 2 inches pipe size shall have a drain hole at least 1/4 inch in diameter.
Valve Size.
A safety valve for a steam boiler shall be:
At least 3/4 inches, unless the boiler and radiating surfaces are a self-contained unit; and
Not larger than 4 1/2 inches.
An inlet opening shall have an inside diameter at least equal to the seat diameter.
The minimum relief capacity of a valve or valves is governed by the capacity marking on the boiler.
Valve Capacity.
Subject to the requirements of §H, below, the minimum valve capacity in pounds per hour is the greater of the capacity determined:
By dividing the maximum BTU output at the boiler nozzle, obtained by firing any fuel for which the unit is installed, by 1,000; or
In accordance with the following table:
